title: Children, Flood and Urban Resilience: Understanding children and young people's experience and agency in the flood recovery process
abstractText:
Relatively few accounts of flooding and flood recovery consider the perspectives of children and young people and the role they might play in building future resilience. Nevertheless, a vital part of building resilience should include taking account of children's perspectives since they are not only community members, but also citizens of the future.

Funded by the ESRC, the Environment Agency and Hull City Council, this project explores children's perspectives on flooding and the recovery process by working with children in two primary schools, one secondary school and a youth group in Hull, a city which experienced major flooding in June 2007.  The methodology includes story boards (where participants can draw, paste pictures or use creative writing to tell their stories of the floods), interviews and focus groups. 

The aim is to identify key issues in their experiences of flooding and flood recovery, the ways in which they can contribute to building resilience to future flood events and to assess the lessons that can be learnt for policy makers. 

The project is further strengthened by contributing to and being undertaken alongside an ongoing ESRC/EPSRC/EA (RES-177-25-0004) project: Flood, Vulnerability and Urban Resilience, a diary based study of the real-time flood recovery process.
